question: What type of city pollution do gas-efficient automobile engines most likely reduce?

content.source_1: Modern fuel‑efficient automobile engines consume less gasoline per mile than older, less efficient engines; other features being equal, this results in less exhaust mass per mile.
content.source_2: Motor‑vehicle exhaust is a major contributor to urban air pollution; when per‑mile emissions drop and total driving does not rise, citywide air pollution declines.
content.source_3: Nitrogen oxides and volatile organic compounds from car exhaust form ground‑level ozone in sunlight; lowering these precursor emissions reduces urban smog.
content.source_4: Improving fuel economy lowers the cost per mile of driving; studies of the rebound effect show that drivers often respond by increasing their total vehicle miles traveled.
content.source_5: Higher traffic volumes and congestion lead to more idling and stop‑and‑go conditions, which can raise total emissions and worsen urban air quality even if individual vehicles are more efficient.
content.source_6: In some urban corridors, growth in vehicle miles traveled has outpaced per‑vehicle emissions reductions, and episodes of worsening air quality have been observed despite more efficient engines.
